tn.text: A new poem begins. See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]].
the stones that made up the temple

tn.ref: at the corner of every street
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:lam:02:18|2:19]] (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Possible meanings are 1) The young men of Jerusalem or 2) all the people of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: they are worth no more than clay jars, the work of the potter's hands!
tn.text: AT: "people consider them to be as worthless as the clay jars that potters make!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the jackals offer the breast to nurse their cubs
tn.text: This means that mother jackals freely allow their babies to nurse.
fierce wild dogs, the worst of unclean animals

This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:lam:02:11|2:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: those who were brought up wearing purple clothing
tn.text: Wearing scarlet clothes was a sign that a person was wealthy.
Possible meanings are 1) "punishment for the sin" or 2) "sin."
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: it was overthrown in a moment
tn.text: "God destroyed it in a moment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: no one lifted a hand to help her
tn.text: "though no one helped her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Her leaders were purer than snow, whiter than milk
tn.text: Possible meanings; 1) "Our leaders were previously beautiful to look at" (UDB) because they were physically healthy or 2) the people loved their leaders because the leaders were morally pure the way new snow and milk are pure white. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jerusalem's leaders
healthy looking
a rock-hard red substance that comes from the ocean used like jewelry
a costly blue stone used in jewelry

tn.ref: Their appearance now is darker than soot
tn.text: This may mean 1) that the sun has darkened the leaders' skin or 2) that the soot from the fires that burned Jerusalem has covered their faces.
AT: "No one can recognize them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: has become as dry as wood
tn.text: because they do not have enough food and water (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Those who have been killed by the sword
tn.text: AT: "Those whom enemy soldiers have killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "those who starve to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
AT: "those who became thin and weak because they were dying from hunger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: pierced by the lack of any harvest from the field
tn.text: Lack of food is spoken of here as if it were a sword. AT: "whom hunger has killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
AT: "Compassionate women" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Yahweh showed all his wrath; he poured out his fierce anger
tn.text: Yahweh was very angry, and he has done everything he wanted to do to show that he was angry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: he poured out his fierce anger
tn.text: God's anger is like a hot, burning liquid that he pours out. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: He kindled a fire in Zion
tn.text: This may mean either 1) that God's anger is like a fire that destroyed Jerusalem, or 2) that God caused enemies to burn Jerusalem with fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The kings of the earth did not believe, nor did any of the inhabitants of the world believe
tn.text: "Nobody anywhere believed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that these are people who desired to harm Jerusalem. AT: "any kind of enemy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: the sins of her prophets and the iniquities of her priests
tn.text: These two lines share similar meanings and emphasize that these spiritual leaders were largely responsible for the fall of Jerusalem. AT: "the terrible sins of her prophets and priests" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: who have shed the blood of the righteous
tn.text: Both the priests and the prophets were guilty of murder. AT: "who have murdered the righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They were so defiled by that blood
tn.text: Because they have committed murder, they are ritually unclean, unable to worship God or be with ordinary people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
scattered the prophets and priests
"not continue to accept them any longer" or "no longer continue to approve of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Our eyes failed, looking in vain for help
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) they looked for people to help them, but no help ever came or 2) they kept on looking for help from people who would never have been able to help them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
AT: "Our enemies followed us everywhere we went" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "The time for us to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This is a title for the king, who provides life to his people like breath keeps the body alive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "pits" refers to the enemies' trap, their plan to catch the king. AT: "the enemies made plans to capture our king, and they did capture him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of gladness. The writer uses these words sarcastically. AT: "Be very glad." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: Daughter of Zion ... daughter of Edom
tn.text: These are poetic names for the people of Jerusalem and of the land of Edom, which are spoken of here as if they were woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: to you also the cup will be passed
tn.text: The wine that people will drink from the cup is a symbol of Yahweh's anger. AT: "Yahweh will also judge you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he will not extend your exile
tn.text: Here the word "he" refers to Yahweh.
"expose your sins"
